Literature Review: Object vision has been a central focus of visual neuroscience for decades, with classic theories primarily emphasizing object recognition. However, recent advancements in behavioral paradigms, neuroscientific methods, and computational modeling have revealed a far more complex and multidimensional representational space underlying human object vision. This literature review aims to synthesize current research on object vision, highlighting the shift from traditional recognition-centric models to a more comprehensive understanding of object representations in the human brain.Traditional theories of object recognition, such as Marr's computational theory of vision, proposed a hierarchical processing stream that transforms retinal images into abstract object representations (Marr, 1982). These models often assumed a single, unified object representation system optimized for recognition. However, recent evidence suggests that object vision is far more complex and multifaceted than previously thought.One significant development in the field has been the application of deep convolutional neural networks (DCNNs) to model human object vision. Yamins and DiCarlo (2016) demonstrated that DCNNs trained on object recognition tasks can predict neural responses in the primate ventral visual stream with remarkable accuracy. This finding has led to a surge of research exploring the parallels between artificial and biological vision systems.However, the success of DCNNs in modeling object recognition has also revealed limitations in our understanding of human object vision. Geirhos et al. (2019) showed that DCNNs and humans differ in their reliance on shape and texture information for object classification, suggesting that current computational models may not fully capture the nuances of human visual processing.The complexity of object representations in the human brain is further evidenced by neuroimaging studies. Haxby et al. (2001) used fMRI to demonstrate that object categories are represented by distinct patterns of activity across the ventral temporal cortex, rather than in discrete regions dedicated to specific categories. This distributed representation challenges the notion of a single, unified object recognition system.Moreover, recent research has highlighted the importance of considering behavioral goals beyond simple recognition. Bracci and Op de Beeck (2016) found that object representations in the visual cortex reflect not only visual properties but also semantic and action-related information. This suggests that the brain's object representations are inherently multidimensional, incorporating various aspects of object knowledge and potential interactions.The role of context in object vision has also gained increased attention. Bar (2004) proposed that the brain uses contextual information to generate predictions about object identity, facilitating rapid recognition. This top-down influence on object processing underscores the dynamic nature of visual representations and their sensitivity to task demands and prior knowledge.Another important aspect of contemporary object vision research is the investigation of temporal dynamics. Cichy et al. (2014) used a combination of MEG and fMRI to reveal the spatiotemporal dynamics of object processing, showing that object category information emerges rapidly and evolves over time. This temporal perspective adds another layer of complexity to our understanding of object representations.The multidimensionality of object representations is further supported by studies examining the relationship between perception and action. Konkle and Caramazza (2013) demonstrated that object size is an organizing principle in the ventral temporal cortex, with large and small objects activating different regions. This finding suggests that object representations are intimately linked to our physical interactions with objects in the environment.Recent work has also challenged the notion of a single, core object recognition system. DiCarlo et al. (2012) proposed that rapid object recognition relies on a feedforward hierarchy in the ventral visual stream. However, subsequent research has revealed the importance of recurrent processing and feedback connections in object vision, particularly for more complex recognition tasks (Kietzmann et al., 2019).In conclusion, the field of object vision has undergone a significant transformation in recent years. While classic theories of object recognition still provide valuable insights, they fail to capture the full complexity of human object vision. The emerging picture is one of a multidimensional representational space that goes far beyond simple recognition, incorporating various aspects of object knowledge, contextual information, and behavioral goals. Future research should continue to explore this complexity, integrating insights from behavioral, neuroscientific, and computational approaches to develop a more comprehensive understanding of how humans perceive and interact with objects in their visual environment.
